segments.text: The sun rises in the valley. It is the
beginning of the new spring season.
Three pig brothers, Bartholomew, Clarence,
and Frank, decide to build new homes.
Bartholomew jumps to play. Clarence likes
to take his time. Frank thinks carefully
about everything.
Straws quick, y'all. I can build this in a
flash. Then I'm fixing to nap before
supper. It'll be a fine lighthouse.
Bartholomew quickly gathers straw and ties
it together. His house stands tall, but
it looks a bit shaky.
I'm done. I think I'll go play in the
creek now.
Clarence starts on his house next.
Wood's sturdier, Bart. Don't want no wind
whipping through. A good strong frame
makes a difference. This will take me a
little longer.
Clarence saws and hammers, putting wooden
planks together. His house is strong and
brown.
Ah,
what a beauty.
Frank, the oldest brother, starts on his
own house.
Bricks are best, strong and steady.
They take the longest, but this house will
last.
Frank mixes mortar and lays each brick
with care. His house is solid and red.
Soon all three houses are ready.
A big hungry wolf walks by. He sniffs the
air and spots the piggies. He approaches
the straw house.
My, oh, my, that smells good.
Little pig, little pig, let me in.
No, sir, not by the hair of my
chinny-chin-chin. You can't come in.
Then I'll huff and I'll puff and I'll blow
your house down.
The wolf takes a deep breath. He huffs and
he puffs with all his might. The straw
house shakes and then falls apart.
Bartholomew screams and runs as fast as
his little legs can carry him.
He dashes to Clarence's wood house.
Two little pigs, let me in. I know you're
in there.
Never. You won't get in here.
The wolf tries again. He huffs and he
puffs. The wood house creaks and groans.
It shakes hard, but it stays up. The wolf
tries one more time, huffing even harder.
The wood house trembles, but it holds
strong.
Bartholomew and Clarence look at each
other, worried. They know they need to get
to Frank's house. They peek out the
window
and see the wolf still huffing. They sneak
out the back door and race to Frank's
brick house.
Three little pigs, let me in. I know
you're all in there now. Not a chance.
This house is made of bricks.
The wolf is very angry now. He takes the
biggest breath he can. He huffs and he
puffs with all his might. He huffs and he
puffs again, pushes hard against the
bricks.
The brick house does not move one bit.
The wolf tries and tries until he is red
in the face.
He is very tired.
He stomps his feet and grumbles. He turns
around and walks away defeated.
The three pigs cheer inside the strong
brick house.
